data.title: When Hitler Faked the Death of his Greatest General

data.text:
It is July 20th, 1944. The cruel sun beams down on the forests of Northwestern Poland. Nestled deep within the forest is a Nazi military complex — the Wolf’s Lair. Twenty-five men surround a long table in a conference room.

At the center of the table, dictating like a mad conductor, stands Adolf Hitler, peering over a map. The topic of the meeting: the German response to their crumbling position on the Eastern Front.

Among the attendees is 36-year-old Count Claus von Stauffenberg. The young general is carrying a briefcase and sweating profusely. He excuses himself to the bathroom to change his shirt.

It is a hot day, but none feel the heat more than the young general. He hears a knock on the door. The meeting is starting. Von Stauffenberg enters and takes his position. He had requested a spot at the table close to Hitler so that he, as an injured soldier, could hear the meeting well.

The request was granted to the maimed, one-eyed officer. But Von Stauffenberg did not care for the contents of the meeting. Had he been completely deaf, it would have all been the same to him.
